data.text: Contents
Complete and reliable collection of information .......................................................... 11
Introduction
Medication errors can cause harm to hospital inpatients, leading to increased morbidity, mortality, poor patient experience and economic burden to health services.
Errors occur most commonly on transfer between care settings and particularly at the time of admission.
Errors may occur at a number of stages during the admission process, including when:
Determining the medication the patient is currently taking, from written records or the accounts of the patient, their families or carers;
Transcribing details of the patient's medication to the hospital drug chart and medical notes (paper or electronic);
Prescribing medication for the patient after admission.

Medicines reconciliation, as defined by the Institute for Healthcare Improvement, is the process of identifying an accurate list of a person's current medicines and comparing them with the current list in use, recognising any discrepancies, and documenting any changes, thereby resulting in a complete list of medicines, accurately communicated (NICE Guidance (NG5)).
At this Trust this is delivered via 3 main routes:
Medical Staff carrying out initial medicines reconciliation for patients admitted to the Trust within 24 hours of admission, or sooner if clinically indicated.

Pharmacy staff providing medicines reconciliation services in clinical areas, prioritised by clinical need. This process should usually be carried out within 24 hours of admission. At weekends this may be longer owing to reduced pharmacy capacity. All pharmacy services are delivered as per service availability.
Medicines reconciliation for elective admissions is also undertaken in pre- assessment clinics. This may be completed by nursing or pharmacy staff.

Where anyone has been involved in the process of medicines reconciliation, it is their responsibility to make sure that any information they have collected is checked  and  communicated,  including  any  changes  they  have  made  (NPC 2008).
Scope

The  purpose  of  this  document  is  to  specify  systems  for  collecting  and documenting  information  about  current  medications  in  order  to  reduce  the incidence  of  medication  errors  on  admission  to  hospital.  This  includes  the process, sourcing of information for drug histories and the data to be collected.
This policy relates to the early management of all newly admitted patients. This includes paediatrics and excludes outpatients (although full drug histories should
be confirmed in these settings). It primarily describes the processes undertaken by pharmacy staff. The same principles are to be applied by nursing staff in the patient pre-assessment clinic.
Definitions

Any difference between the medicines the patient had been taking in their previous care setting and the medicines prescribed in their new care setting. Discrepancies may be considered as intentional or unintentional.

Discharge Medicines Service. A new Essential service within the Community Pharmacy Contractual Framework (CPCF). This service means NHS Trusts are able to refer patients who would benefit from extra guidance around new prescribed medicines for provision of the DMS at their community pharmacy.
Refers to the Trust in-patient prescribing and administration record; Depending on the location/department, this may be a paper- based chart or Wellsky ePMA.
Lorenzo patient record systems are a type of Electronic health record provided by DXC Technology, originally as part of the United Kingdom government's National Programme for IT in the NHS.

The process of identifying an accurate list of a person's current medicines and comparing them with the current list in use, recognising any discrepancies, and documenting any changes, thereby resulting in a complete list of medicines, accurately communicated
National Institute of Health and Care Excellence
Over-the-counter medication. For the purposes of this document this also includes medication purchased from retail outlets without restriction.
This is the ward-based clinical team comprising of a ward pharmacist and appropriately competency trained pharmacy technician or pre-registration pharmacist.

electronic message to a patient's nominated community pharmacy at discharge. This is to provide recommendations or information as part of the community pharmacy Discharge Medicines Service.

In the context of medicines reconciliation timescales this is by the end of the following day after patient admission to the Trust. This is taken from the date the patient is clerked in by the admitting doctor.

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group
Receiving exception reports and taking action in response to issues raised from Medicines Assurance Group and/or department of pharmacy.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nurse or Site Director of Nursing or Medical Director as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning medicines reconciliation.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Monitoring through incident reports, through assessment of trends and themes;
Escalating issues to site divisional governance groups and MAG as appropriate.
MSE Pharmacy Directorate Board
Tracking pharmacy medicine reconciliation audit monthly;
Ensuring quality improvement actions are tracked and delivered with respect to pharmacy service delivery.
Chief Executive

As the Trust's Accountable Officer has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date documents in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Medical Officer, delegating to site Medical Directors
Ensuring that there is policy compliance by all professions they oversee and assuring themselves that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated medicines reconciliation issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Divisional Clinical Directors & Specialty Directors
Ensuring prescribers are implementing and monitoring management in their areas;
Ensuring areas under their responsibility are appropriately monitored and supported following audit to ensure sustained improvement is achieved.
Chief Nursing Officer, delegating to Site Directors of Nursing
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place, where nursing take a role in medicines reconciliation, to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated medicines reconciliation issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
Associate Directors of Nursing and Matrons

Ensuring areas under their responsibility are appropriately monitored and supported following audit to ensure sustained improvement is achieved, in relation to elements of this policy involving nurses.
Chief Pharmacist
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standards.
Ensuring that KPI's are submitted to the appropriate group.
Medical staff
Actively encouraging patients/carers to bring in patient medication information on admission, including patient's own medicines;
Collecting and recording all paper- based patient medication information obtained;
Thorough patient clerking, reviewing the available information and making an informed and documented decision as to the appropriate medication required for the patient;
Documenting their initial medication history in the patient's medical notes, the format of which may vary according to directorate;

Ensuring the quality and accuracy of their medication history on admission, and recognising any limitations of this process that need to be urgently followed up; referring to pharmacy team where appropriate;

Following up outstanding issues relating to a medication history undertaken by themselves and for any patient under their care. This will include the review of a pharmacy-led or nurse-led medication history as documented on a designated note on Wellsky ePMA or section of paper drug chart (where used) or where highlighted in the medical notes;
Ensuring outstanding medication-related issues are clearly documented within handover communications between medical teams so that they may be promptly resolved;

Documenting clearly any medication changes, with clear reasons, from the medication history list and maintaining this record throughout the patient stay. This will ensure essential information can be communicated back to primary care on discharge (i.e. via the discharge summary);

Ensuring that they prescribe all the correct medication for a patient on an in- patient prescription chart for the patient's hospital stay in accordance with Trust Prescribing of Medicines Policy (or equivalent).
Pharmacy team
Actively encouraging patients/carers to bring in patient medication information on admission, including patient's own medicines;
Collecting and recording all paper-based patient medication information in patient notes;
Checking the drug history taken by the admitting doctor. In doing so they should carry out a full multi-source check in accordance with this policy and pharmacy departmental procedures;

Aiming to reconcile the patient's medicines history within 24 hours of admission, and prioritising patients with the highest need based on clinical judgement (e.g. weekend admissions, critical patients);
Ensuring the quality and accuracy of their medication history, and recognising any limitations of this process that need to be urgently followed up;
Following up outstanding issues relating to a medication history undertaken by themselves and for any patient under their care;

Identifying medication discrepancies and documenting them accurately and clearly, for medical review. This should be recorded on the drug chart using the medication reconciliation section (paper) or via the medicines reconciliation notes system on Wellsky ePMA (electronic);

Supporting medical staff in the clear recording of any medication changes, with clear reasons, from the medication history list and maintaining this record throughout the patient stay. This will ensure essential information can be communicated back to primary care on discharge (i.e. via the discharge summary);
Consenting patients for the Discharge Medicines Service via PharmOutcomes for onward referral, where appropriate, in preparation for discharge;

Communicating outstanding issues to prescribers, and nursing staff, as appropriate, in a timely manner. This will be carried out in a consistent manner in accordance with pharmacy departmental procedures.
Pharmacist (additional to pharmacy staff role above)
Clinically screening the drug chart, including a review of the drug history and identified discrepancies, resolving where possible and/or referring to prescriber for resolution;
Supporting pharmacy technical staff in processing the clinical elements of medicines reconciliation;
Ensuring relevant information is entered within the PharmOutcomes submission to DMS on discharge, in accordance with pharmacy departmental procedures;
Making appropriate records on Wellsky ePMA in line with departmental procedures to support accurate statistical reporting.
Ward/department nursing staff
Actively encouraging patients/carers to bring in patient medication information on admission, including patient's own medicines;
Collecting and recording all paper-based patient medication information in patient notes;
Ensuring complete transfer of medication and information related to medicines with the patient on transfer within the Trust;

Documenting any medication discrepancies identified through the course of administering medicines within WellSky ePMA and / or medical notes that require follow-up by the medical team and/or pharmacy staff.
Escalating discrepancies to prescriber / pharmacist for further review, dependent upon clinical urgency of the discrepancy;
Referring back to the prescribing doctor for clarification before administration occurs if there are any concerns regarding the prescription.
Pre-assessment clinic registered staff undertaking medicines reconciliation
Encouraging patients to bring in their own medicines, in sufficient quantity, when they are admitted to hospital;
Ensuring the quality and accuracy of their medication history, and recognising any limitations of this process that need to be urgently followed
up;
Following up outstanding issues relating to a medication history undertaken by themselves and for any patient under their care;
Documenting the medication history clearly in the patient's medical notes, and retain any related documents provided by the patient.
Collecting Information General Principles

This involves the collection of the medication history. Ideally this should be multisource and always involve the patient, where possible. In some cases this should be done with caution (i.e. patient suffering from a condition where they may be an inaccurate source of information e.g. advanced dementia, delirium). All staff should note that this does not mean a patient with dementia should not be spoken to as part of the medication history process.
All staff should be vigilant of patient communication difficulties and adapt their approach accordingly. This can be achieved by utilising a range of different sources outlined in this document.
Lifestyle, Religious and Cultural beliefs

5.3.1 A consideration of a patient's lifestyle, religious and cultural beliefs must be undertaken when evaluating information provided. For example medicines reconciliation should capture information on recreational drug, OTC medication and complimentary /alternative medicine use. These may be essential in detecting a serious adverse reaction or drug interaction.
5.3.2 Information concerning intentional omission of medicines (i.e. fasting) and specific requirements (e.g. non-gelatine preparation) should also be determined.
Primary Care Assistance

5.4.1  Primary care should assist the relevant hospital staff (doctors, nurses, pharmacy staff) in the medicines reconciliation process. It is requested that all patients are admitted from primary care with a sufficient amount of information about their medication and medical history.
Consenting for Discharge Medicines Service (DMS)

5.5.1 Patients should be consented to participate in the community pharmacy Discharge Medicines Service, by pharmacy staff. The DMS is designed to support medicines reconciliation on the transfer of care from our hospitals back to the patient's home or place of care.

5.5.2 Consenting will involve discussion of the benefits of the service and obtaining the patients preferred community pharmacy for the hospital to refer to on discharge. A leaflet is available that is provided to patients.
5.5.3 Community pharmacies will receive a discharge medicines list and any details about medication on discharge (see section 10.4).
Complete and reliable collection of information
The minimum information to be available on admission should include:
Complete patient details i.e. full name, date of birth, weight in kg;
NHS number, GP, date of admission;
Presenting condition plus co-morbidities;
A list of medicines currently prescribed, including those bought over the counter, recreational drugs and alternative medicines used;
Dose, frequency, formulation and route of the medicines listed;
An indication of medicines that are not intended to be continued;
Known allergies (with type of reaction recorded) and previous drug adverse reactions.
Sources of information
The medication history should be collected from the most recent, reliable and complete source.
The person recording that information should always record the date and time that the information was obtained and the source of the information used.

All staff should take extreme care to ensure information is recent. Generally this can be considered as within 1 month of admission, where verified that no other medication intervention has occurred in the intervening period. Where the information is obtained from pre-assessment clinic, the length of time since clinic date should be noted to assess validity. Also note the sources from which the drug history was taken during pre-assessment clinic as in some cases, there may have been insufficient sources available during the clinic appointment.

If in any doubt (i.e. no date on paperwork) that information source must not be relied on in isolation. Always check you have the complete information (e.g. all pages of a document). If paperwork is provided loose, secure them together using a staple.
Information may be obtained from a variety of sources (some potentially more reliable than others).
In all instances the patient should be spoken to where possible and appropriate.
Sources of information

7.7.1 The following sources of drug histories are listed below in no order of preference, as reliability can vary according to the situation. However, it may often be necessary to use two or more sources to establish an accurate drug history. Judgement must be used as to reliability of using only source.
7.7.2 The Patient
This is an important source as the patient will tell you exactly how they take their medicines;
Always try to establish how exactly a patient takes their medicines, as this could be very different from the formal records.
7.7.3 Patients Own Drugs (POD's)
Encourage patients to bring in their medicines from home;
Most useful when used in conjunction with the patient for confirmation;
Do not assume that the dispensing label accurately reflects patient usage - check the date of dispensing since some patients may bring all their medicines into hospital, including those stopped;
Cross-reference against clinic letters – has the dose been changed since the PODs dispensed?
7.7.4 Relatives/carers
Patients may have relatives, friends or carers who help them with their medicines. This is common with elderly patients or with patients where English is not their first language;
Carers can be very helpful in establishing an accurate drug history and can also give an insight into how medicines are managed at home;
Be mindful of maintaining confidentiality.
7.7.5 Summary Care Record
Gain permission from the patient to view information from their GP records. If unable to gain permission, emergency access may be used;
Date of last issue must be considered – where this is not clear or not recorded (e.g. only date of authorisation shown), this must be confirmed with another source;
Confirm with a second source wherever possible as SCRs are not always kept up to date, particularly where the patient has had recent changes to medications following a recent hospital admission etc
7.7.6 Repeat prescriptions
Some patients keep copies of all their repeat prescriptions. Many of these may include medicines that have been stopped;
The date of issue should always be checked and each item confirmed with the patient;
If there is any doubt, the GP surgery should be contacted.
7.7.7 GP referral letters
These are not always reliable;
The chart should be checked through with the patient and the date of issue noted.
7.7.8 Recent hospital discharge summary
Check whether any changes have been made by the GP since the patient's previous discharge from hospital;
Discharge summaries that are more than one month old should not be used as a sole source for a drug history.
7.7.9 Residential/Nursing home records e.g. Medication Administration Record (MAR) sheets.
Useful and accurate source for a drug history;
Usually sent in with the patient;
Handwritten lists from homes should be used with caution as they often have transcription errors;
Care should be taken to ensure all pages have been reviewed and none are missing – usually requires confirmation from another source.
7.7.10 In some cases it may be necessary to investigate additional sources to obtain a complete medication history. Examples of teams that may need to be contacted for further information include:
Anticoagulant clinics;
Community pharmacists;
Specialist nurses e.g. heart failure/asthma nurse;
Drug and alcohol service;
Renal dialysis unit;
Other hospitals for clinical trials/unlicensed medicines.
7.7.11 Where possible, double check with the patient/carer as to how he/she takes the medicines, as this may not be the same as on the prescription.
Medication for Substance Addiction/Misuse

Occasionally patients will present requesting medication that is usually prescribed on a substance misuse programme (e.g. methadone 1mg/1ml mixture). See guideline on the management of opioid withdrawal in adults (or equivalent).
Checking Information
This is the process of ensuring that the medications and doses which are now prescribed for the patient are correct.

The collected drug history must now be cross referenced against the medication currently charted. Prescribed medication may not be identical to those contained in the medication history. This may be due to intentional changes or unintended errors.

Pharmacy will document any intentional changes or unintentional errors on the designated section on the drug chart (paper) or within Wellsky ePMA using the medicines reconciliation note and doctor's note, if needed, as detailed within their departmental procedures as part of this process.
Communicating Information
This is the final step in the process where any issues raised from the medication history are documented and dated, ready to be communicated to the next person that sees them.

Medication information collected and checked during medicines reconciliation must only be entered in the designated section/s of the drug chart (paper or Wellsky ePMA, as applicable) and/or documented in the medical notes.
This will include such things as:

Medicines that have been stopped or initiated, and for what reason. This will then facilitate the documentation of this information on the discharge summary (a copy of which is provided to the patient);
The intended duration of treatment (e.g. for antibiotics and hypnotics);
When a dose, route or frequency has been changed;
Any long-term medication that has been stopped or started.

On discharge, the pharmacy team should communicate the information, at point of discharge, within section 10.3 to the community pharmacy DMS (see also section 5.5). This is done via PharmOutcomes in line with pharmacy departmental procedures. Please also refer to the discharge medication policy (or equivalent).
Discrepancies

Where there appears to be a discrepancy between what the patient is currently prescribed, and what the patient is actually taking, this should be recorded together with reasons for variation, where these can be established.

Within Wellsky ePMA, discrepancies are listed within the medicines reconciliation note. As a minimum this will list the name of medication, strength, route, form and frequency. The paper drug chart (where used) has a designated section for this purpose.

Discrepancies should be triaged by clinical importance by the pharmacist screening the drug history and referred to prescribers for review. This may involve a verbal communication and/or entry into the patient's medical record if deemed appropriate. Where there is verbal communication, this should always be followed up with an entry in the medical notes if the discrepancy is not resolved immediately.

For paper charts it is NOT acceptable to solely apply notes (such as sticky notes) as this is known to lead to errors where mismatched between patients. Any written communication should be in the medical notes/ ePMA notes.
Where a discrepancy is confirmed as an intentional change, the reason for the change should be documented in the medical notes and/or the drug chart (if it is not already clear).

Where an unintentional omission has been identified, this must never be added by pharmacy to the prescribing area of the drug chart or be prescribed in the case of Wellsky ePMA (unless the person is a registered prescriber and therefore taking full legal responsibility for the entry).
The only exception to this will be where an appropriate healthcare professional has confirmed its appropriateness directly with a prescriber and has their approval.
This must always be documented:

Where an unintentional change in frequency/dose/formulation is identified, this may be amended by a member of pharmacy staff ensuring it is dated and endorsed with the initials of the professional making the amendment/adding additional information (paper chart). This will be automatically recorded on WellSky ePMA.
Where this amendment has been confirmed with the prescriber
The person making the amendment is responsible for the accuracy of any information they transcribe to the chart.
Training Requirements

All pharmacy staff undertakes formal medicines reconciliation training including face to face teaching under supervision. They are required to complete competency assessment logs before working unsupervised.

data.text: Appendix 2: Collecting information for medicines reconciliation
The ‘collecting' step involves taking a medication history and collecting other
relevant information about the patient's medicines. The information may come from a range of different sources (some potentially more reliable than others).
The medication history should be collected from the most recent and reliable

sources. Where possible, information should be cross-checked and verified. The person recording the information should always record the date that the information was obtained and the source of the information.
This section covers:
Taking a medication history
A checklist of questions that can support medicines reconciliation and help to identify any problems
Sources that can be used to take medication histories
Taking a medication history
Introduce yourself to the patient, confirm you are talking to the correct patient, and explain the purpose of your visit.

Confirm with the patient whether they have any medication allergies or adverse drug reactions (ADRs). Ask also about the nature of the reaction and document this information in the drug allergy/hypersensitivity box on the medication record chart:
If the patient has no known drug allergies/hypersensitivities, then document as ‘NKDA'. If the patient is unconscious/ unavailable use other sources to determine allergy status where possible.
Ask the patient if they have brought their own medicines and/or a list of their medicines into hospital.
Ascertain what medicines the patient was using regularly in their previous care setting prior to admission (see section below on sources for drug histories).
Ask the patient for details of medicine name, formulation, strength and frequency of administration (including times) for each medication.
If appropriate gain permission from the patient to view information from their GP records. If unable to gain permission, emergency access may be used.

Where the patient has been transferred from another care setting, you may need to check the medication history against the medication record chart or administration record from that setting. You may need to use your discretion and reconcile medicines from prior to admission to the previous care setting.
The first source of documentation of a medication history on admission should always be the patient medical record.

In addition to asking the patient about regularly prescribed medicines, also check if the patient is using any inhalers, eye drops, topical preparations, once weekly medications, injections, OTC medicines, herbal products, oral contraceptives, hormone replacement therapy or has home nebules or home oxygen – these are often forgotten by patients.
Ascertain the patient's adherence to their prescribed medication regime. Ask the patient/carer if they take/administer the medicines as labelled. Ask if they use a compliance aid.

Note: Some patients are confused on admission to hospital and state they are not taking any medicines. If unsure as to the reliability of a patient's answer, another source of information must be used to confirm.
Specific information should be collected about the following drugs:
Warfarin
The following points should be recorded on the drug chart for patients taking warfarin:
Indication, duration of treatment and target INR
Patient's usual or most recent dose
Recent INRs if known
Whether patient has an anticoagulant “yellow” book
Steroids
It is important to obtain an accurate history particularly for patients with asthma or COPD, IBD or arthritis.
Ask about any recent courses (within past 6 months):
For those on long-term steroids this should be annotated on the drug chart so that treatment is not abruptly stopped.
Insulin
The type (human, bovine or pork), brand, administration device and dose should always be checked and annotated on the drug chart.
For those patients that say that they have an insulin pen, clarify between a pre-filled disposable pen and a penfill cartridge.
Oral contraceptives /HRT
These are not always considered as medicines by the patient and should therefore be asked for.
Methotrexate
This is prescribed once weekly so the day of administration, strength, route of administration, and number of tablets (if applicable) taken should be confirmed with the patient.
Check that this is correct on the drug chart and that the six days of the week when the dose is not to be administered are crossed off.
Any concomitant folic acid prescriptions should also be asked about.
Bisphosphonates
The day of administration should be confirmed with the patient and annotated on the drug chart. Ask the patient whether they take calcium preparations and confirm which brand.
Inhalers
It is important to confirm the name, strength and type of inhaler.
Methadone
Refer to the Trust Management of opioid withdrawal in adult's guideline, or equivalent.
Nebulisers
Identify whether the patient has own nebuliser and nebules at home and document on the drug chart.
HIV meds

Consider that these medications may not be on the GP records and consent may be required to add them on to the drug history. However, note that this is unlikely to be unknown to the GP and, due to the high number of interactions with these medications, it is important to include them where possible.
Chemotherapy
These medications are unlikely to be on central GP records and may need clarification with the local oncology team or hospital dispensing records. Ensure course length is confirmed.
A checklist of questions to support medicines reconciliation and help identify
any problems
Does anyone help you with your medicines at home? If so, who? What do they do?
Do you have any problems obtaining or ordering your repeat prescriptions (NB: relative / carer might help)
Do you have a regular community pharmacy that you use?
Do you have problems getting medicines out of their packages?
Do you have problems reading the labels?
Some people forget to take their medicines from time to time. Do you? What do you do to help you remember?
Some people take more or less of a medicine depending on how they feel. Do you ever do this?
Most medicines have side-effects. Do you have any from your medicines?
Specific medication related questions such as, “Have any medicines been stopped recently” or “Have any doses been changed recently”?
